questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents with sudden, severe visual loss following a recent road traffic accident involving chest trauma. Fundus examination reveals multiple white retinal patches near the optic disc, cotton wool spots, and minimal intraretinal hemorrhage. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Purtscher Retinopathy is a condition typically associated with trauma (especially head or chest trauma) and is characterized by multiple retinal white patches around the optic nerve head and fovea, known as Purtscher flecken, cotton wool spots, and minimal intraretinal hemorrhage.

The occlusion of peripapillary arterioles and embolization is the key pathophysiological mechanism. In this case, the sudden severe visual loss after trauma, along with the described retinal findings, suggests Purtscher Retinopathy.

Purtscher Retinopathy

Feature

Description

Etiology

Trauma (head, chest), fractures, systemic diseases like SLE, pancreatitis, pre-eclampsia.

Fundoscopy features
  • Purtscher Flecken: White patches near the optic disc and fovea due to arteriolar occlusion.
  • Cotton Wool Spots: Infarcts in the nerve fiber layer, typically restricted to the posterior pole.
  • Retinal Hemorrhages: Small, low-to-moderate hemorrhages.

Diagnostic Criteria

Requires 3 out of 5:

  • Purtscher flecken
  • Hemorrhages
  • Cotton wool spots
  • Plausible cause
  • Investigation compatible with the diagnosis

Ocular investigations
  • Fundus Fluorescein Angiography (FFA): Reveals macular ischemia, capillary nonperfusion, and optic nerve head leakage.
  • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): Demonstrates retinal thickening, subretinal fluid, and photoreceptor loss in later stages.
  • OCT Angiography: Can show retinal capillary ischemia.

Management

Supportive care, steroids, anti-VEGF for macular edema.

 

Diabetic Retinopathy (Option A) is associated with microvascular changes due to diabetes, including dot-blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and neovascularization, but not Purtscher flecken or trauma-related visual loss.

 

Retinal Vein Occlusion (Option B) presents with diffuse retinal hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and optic disc swelling but is not typically linked to trauma.

 

Central Serous Retinopathy (Option D) involves serous retinal detachment usually due to stress, without the hemorrhages or cotton wool spots seen in Purtscher Retinopathy.

questions.text: A 30-week premature infant weighing 1.4 kg is diagnosed with stage 3 retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) in zone II without plus disease. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Stage 3 ROP without plus disease in zone II is considered to be Low risk Pre threshold. It typically warrants close observation with follow-up rather than immediate treatment unless there are signs of progression.

Anatomical classification of ROP by Zones:

Zone I

Bounded by a circle, the radius of which is twice the distance between the center of the optic disc and center of the macula.

Zone II

Extends from the edge of the zone 1 peripherally to a point tangential to the nasal ora serrata.

Zone III

Consists of residual temporal crescent of retina anterior to zone II.

 

  • Threshold Disease: Stage 3+ ROP with plus disease.
    • Located in zone I or II.
    • Involves 5 continuous or 8 discontinuous clock hours.
    • Requires laser therapy within 72 hours.
  • Prethreshold Disease: Classified by the Early Treatment for Retinopathy of Prematurity (ET-ROP) group into two types:

 

 

Type I

Type II

High-Risk Prethreshold Disease, requiring laser photocoagulation.

  • Zone I: Plus disease, any stage.
  • Zone I: Non-plus disease, stage 3.
  • Zone II: Plus disease, stages 2 and 3. (Option A)

Low-Risk Prethreshold Disease, requiring weekly follow-up.

  • Zone I: Non-plus disease, stages 1 and 2.
  • Zone II: Non-plus disease, stage 3. (Option C)

 

Treatment of ROP:

  1. Laser treatment: (Option A)
    • Done in the avascular peripheral retina.
    • Use diode laser or frequency doubled Nd:YAG with LIO (laser indirect ophthalmoscope) delivery.
    • Used for high-risk pre-threshold, threshold, and aggressive posterior ROP.
  2. Anti-VEGF: (Option B)
    • Bevacizumab: Effective in patients with zone I, stage 3 ROP with plus disease.
    • Zone I disease responds more than zone II.
    • Recurrence can occur following cessation of anti-VEGF treatment.
  3. Pars plana vitrectomy: For tractional retinal detachment not involving macula.

 

Cryotherapy of retina (Option D) is not preferred for stage 3 ROP, especially in zone II without plus disease. It has been largely replaced by laser therapy due to its higher risk of causing inflammation and less favorable outcomes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden, painless vision loss in his right eye. On examination, the right eye shows a pale retina with a cherry-red spot at the macula. The patient has a history of hypertension and smoking. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment to improve retinal blood flow and potentially restore vision?

choices.text: Ocular massage and anterior chamber paracentesis

questions.solution:
The goal of the initial treatment is to restore retinal blood flow. Ocular massage and anterior chamber paracentesis are commonly used methods to dislodge emboli and improve perfusion.

 

Treatment Goals

Restore Blood Flow

Dislodge or break down the blockage in the central retinal artery as quickly as possible.

Minimize Retinal Damage

Limit the duration of ischemia to reduce permanent damage to retinal tissue.

Address Underlying Conditions

Identify and manage underlying conditions like atherosclerosis, hypertension, and cardiac diseases.

Treatment Options

Ocular Massage (within 24 hrs)

Apply pressure to the globe to dislodge the embolus; performed using a three-mirror contact lens.

Anterior Chamber Paracentesis

Withdraw aqueous humor to decrease intraocular pressure, potentially dislodging the embolus.

Medications to Lower IOP

  

Topical Apraclonidine & Timolol

Reduce aqueous humor production to lower IOP

Intravenous Acetazolamide (Option C)

Provides sustained IOP reduction

Vasodilators

  

Sublingual Isosorbide Dinitrate (Option D)

Dilates blood vessels to improve blood flow past the blockage

Carbon Dioxide Inhalation

  

"Rebreathing" into a Paper Bag

Increases carbon dioxide levels to induce vasodilation

Carbogen Breathing

Controlled inhalation of high oxygen (95%) and carbon dioxide (5%) mixtures to induce vasodilation and slow down ischemia.

Hyperosmotic agents

Mannitol or glycerol (Option A&B)

Rapid IOP-lowering effect and raised intravascular volume

Transluminal Nd:YAG laser embolysis/embolectomy

For BRAO and CRAO where an occluding embolus is visible; Good final visual results achieved

Thrombolysis

  

Local Intra-arterial or Intravenous

Directly dissolve clots with thrombolytic agents; efficacy in CRAO is inconclusive.

Local Intraocular Thrombolysis

Use of rtPA for thrombolysis; large trials show no significant benefit

Systemic Management

  

Urgent Referral

Immediate evaluation by a stroke specialist due to high stroke risk.

Management of Risk Factors

Smoking Cessation

Reduce overall vascular risk.

Cardiac Arrhythmia Management

Refer to a physician for conditions like atrial fibrillation.

Antiplatelet Therapy

To reduce further blood clot formation, unless contraindicated.

Oral Anticoagulation

Warfarin or other anticoagulants for conditions like atrial fibrillation

Carotid Endarterectomy

Considered for significant carotid artery stenosis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a 20-year history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes and an HbA1c of 10.5% came for an ophthalmic examination. Fundoscopy reveals microaneurysms, hard exudates, and retinal thickening. Which of the following is the most likely cause of future vision loss in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- (Option C) Macular Edema

Complications of Diabetic Retinopathy:

1. Macular Edema: (Option C)

  • Most common cause of vision loss in diabetic retinopathy is leakage from dilated capillaries.
  • Clinically significant macular edema (CSME):
    • Retinal thickening at the center of the macula.
    • Retinal thickening and/or adjacent hard exudates at or within 500 µ of the center of the macula.
    • An area of retinal thickening greater than or equal to one disc area, any part of which is within 1 disc diameter of the center of the macula.
  • Types: Focal or Diffuse macular edema
  • Diagnosis:
    • Slit-lamp Biomicroscopy: Loss of foveal reflex and macular thickening
    • Fluorescein Angiography Identifies leakage and also diagnoses ischemic maculopathy.

  • Treatment:
    • Anti-VEGF Therapy: Bevacizumab, ranibizumab or aflibercept.
      • Laser treatment should be deferred for 6 months after commencement of anti-VEGF injection.
    • Intravitreal Triamcinolone acetonide: Reduce macular edema and improve visual acuity.
    • Photocoagulation:
      • Focal Photocoagulation: Treatment of choice for focal diabetic macular edema (DME) not involving the center of the fovea using diode or argon burns.
      • Grid Photocoagulation: Considered in recalcitrant cases unresponsive to anti-VEGF agents or intravitreal steroids. Burns are applied to macular areas of diffuse retinal thickening, treating no closer than 500 µ from the foveola and 500 µ from the optic disc.

 

2. Vitreous Hemorrhage (VH): (Option A)

  • Seen as blood floating in the vitreous, occluding the view of the retina.
  • Secondary to proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is a cause of severe vision loss in diabetic patients.
  • In PDR, fibrovascular tissue lies flat on the retina or attaches to the posterior vitreous, leading to vitreous traction, retinal separation, and vessel rupture. This is the most common cause of VH in adults.

 

3. Retinal Detachment: (Option B)

  • PDR causes scars to form in the back of the eye. When the scars pull the retina away from the back of the eye, it's called tractional retinal detachment.

 

4. Neovascular Glaucoma: (Option D)

  • PDR causes abnormal blood vessels to grow out of the retina and block fluid from draining out of the eye, leading to neovascular glaucoma.
  • Can cause vision loss and blindness.

 

5. Rubeosis Iridis:

  • Neovascularization of iris, is when blood vessels develop on the anterior surface of the iris in response to retinal ischemia.
  • Prone to spontaneous hyphema as the blood vessels are fragile.
  • Treatment: Panretinal photocoagulation with or without intravitreal injection of anti-VEGF.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male with long-standing hypertension comes for a routine eye checkup. On fundoscopy, the ophthalmologist observes the following changes as shown in the image below. What is the most likely stage of hypertensive retinopathy?
questions.solution:
The fundoscopy image shows Grade III Hypertensive Retinopathy characterized by generalized arteriolar narrowing, hard exudates arranged in a macular star pattern, and cotton wool spots with no papilledema.

 

Hypertensive retinopathy refers to retinal changes seen in patients with systemic hypertension. The condition's development involves several pathological mechanisms, including vasospasm, arteriosclerosis, increased vascular permeability, and raised intracranial pressure.

 

Pathogenesis:

The pathophysiology of hypertensive retinopathy is thought to progress through overlapping, non-sequential stages: The vasoconstrictive phase, Exudative phase, Sclerotic phase, and complications arising from the sclerotic phase.

  • Vasospasm: The initial reaction to elevated blood pressure is retinal arteriolar narrowing due to vasospasm. This is more noticeable in younger patients and leads to ischemia in the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), choroid, and optic nerve head.
  • Arteriosclerosis: Arteriosclerotic changes reflect chronic hypertension. These changes are associated with the thickening of vessel walls, leading to arteriolar reflex alterations and arteriovenous (A-V) crossing abnormalities.
  • Increased Vascular Permeability: Severe hypertension causes hypoxia and breakdown of the inner blood-retinal barrier, leading to retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and macular edema.
  • Raised Intracranial Pressure: Seen in malignant hypertension, causing hypertensive optic neuropathy characterized by papilledema and optic nerve ischemia.

 

Clinical Features:

1. Benign (Chronic) Hypertensive Retinopathy:

  • Generalized arteriolar narrowing: May be mild or marked, with vasoconstrictive and sclerotic phases.
  • Focal arteriolar narrowing: Localized vasoconstriction near the disc.
  • A-V nicking: Compression of veins at A-V crossings, Salus's sign (right-angle deflection of veins at arteriovenous crossings), Bonnet sign (banking of veins distal to arteriovenous crossings), and Gunn sign (tapering of veins on either side of the crossings)

 

.

  • Arteriolar reflex changes: Brightening of light reflex in younger individuals, with copper wiring (reddish-brown reflex of the arterioles occurs due to progressive sclerosis and hyalinization) and silver wiring (opaque- white reflex of the arterioles due to the continued sclerosis) seen in advanced disease.
    Fig: Copper Wiring


Fig: Silver Wiring

  • Retinal hemorrhages: Flame-shaped hemorrhages at the posterior pole.
  • Hard exudates: Yellowish deposits in the retina, arranged in a macular-star pattern.
  • Cotton wool spots: Fluffy white areas representing nerve fiber infarctions.

2. Malignant Hypertensive Retinopathy:

  • Acute retinal changes: Marked arteriolar narrowing, flame-shaped hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots.
  • Choroidal involvement: Focal retinal pigment epithelium changes, Elschnig's spots, and Siegrist streaks due to choroidal ischemia.
  • Optic neuropathy: Disc edema and hemorrhages in the peripapillary area due to ischemia from vasoconstriction of choroidal vessels.

Staging of Hypertensive Retinopathy (Keith and Wagner Classification):

Stage

Key Features

Grade I (Option A)

Mild generalized arteriolar narrowing, broadening of the light reflex.
 

Grade II (Option B)

Focal arteriolar narrowing, A-V nicking (Salu’s sign)

Grade III (Option C)

Flame-shaped hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and more pronounced A-V nicking (Bonnet and Gunn signs), hemorrhages, and exudates.

Grade IV (Option D)

All features of Grade III + Papilledema, Silver-wiring of arterioles.
 

 

Management:

  • Mild Retinopathy: Blood pressure control.
  • Moderate Retinopathy: Blood pressure control and evaluation of vascular risk factors.
  • Malignant Retinopathy: Careful and gradual reduction of blood pressure to prevent sudden perfusion loss.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with complaints of severe headache and blurred vision. His blood pressure is 220/120 mmHg. Fundoscopy image is given below. Which of the following fundus changes is most characteristic of this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given fundus photograph demonstrates:
     
    • Blurred optic disc margins → Papilledema
       
    • Flame-shaped hemorrhages
       
    • Retinal exudates
       
    • Venous dilation
       
    • Narrowed arterioles
       
    • Additional features of malignant hypertensive retinopathy may include Elschnig’s spots and Siegrist’s streaks.
       
  • These findings, combined with very high BP (220/120 mmHg) and neurological symptoms (headache, blurred vision), confirm malignant hypertensive retinopathy, where papilledema is a hallmark and diagnostic.

 

 

Fundoscopy Findings in Malignant Hypertensive Retinopathy:

Finding

Description

Papilledema

Swelling of optic disc due to raised intracranial pressure and optic nerve ischemia

Exudates

Lipid deposits; may form a macular star

Retinal hemorrhages

Flame-shaped hemorrhages, especially in posterior pole

Cotton wool spots

Ischemic infarcts of nerve fiber layer

Venous dilation

Result of vascular congestion

Narrowing of arterioles

Severe vasospasm in acute cases

Elschnig’s spots

Black spots with yellow halos from choroidal infarcts

Siegrist’s streaks

Linear pigmentation along choroidal arterioles from fibrinoid necrosis

 

Hypertensive Retinopathy:

Feature

Chronic Hypertensive Retinopathy

Malignant Hypertensive Retinopathy

Arteriolar narrowing

Generalized or focal narrowing, A-V nicking (Option A)

Marked narrowing due to vasospasm

Retinal reflex changes

Copper-wiring (Option B), silver-wiring

Not prominent

Retinal hemorrhages

Few flame-shaped at posterior pole

Numerous flame-shaped hemorrhages

Exudates

Hard exudates, macular-star (Option D)

Focal intraretinal periarterial transudates (FIPTs)

Cotton wool spots

Present

More prominent and widespread

Choroidal involvement

Absent

Elschnig’s spots, Siegrist’s streaks

Optic neuropathy

Absent/minimal

Papilledema, optic nerve ischemia


 

Arteriovenous nicking (Option A):
Seen in chronic hypertensive changes, not specific to acute or malignant phases.
 

Copper-wiring (Option B):
Characteristic of chronic arteriosclerotic changes, not acute hypertensive crisis.
 

Hard exudates (Option D):
Present in both chronic and acute stages, but not diagnostic. Papilledema is the hallmark of malignant hypertension.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of uncontrolled hypertension presents for a routine eye examination. Fundoscopy reveals arteriolar narrowing and changes in the arteriovenous (A-V) ratio. What is the most likely A-V ratio finding in this patient with hypertensive retinopathy?
questions.solution: In hypertensive retinopathy, arteriolar narrowing occurs as a result of vasoconstriction and thickening of the vessel walls. This causes a change in the normal A-V ratio to 1:3. In normal fundoscopy, the ratio of the diameters of first- and second-order retinal arterioles to the diameters of venules is approximately 2:3.

questions.text: All of the following are considered risk factors for the development of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO), except?
questions.solution:
Hyperthyroidism is not associated with an increased risk of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). It primarily affects metabolism and does not directly influence the vascular system, predisposing to CRVO.

 

CRVO – Etiology:

 

Factors

Details

Primary Risk Factors
  • Age > 50 years (primary risk factor) (Option A),
  • Hypertension (Option D),
  • Open-angle glaucoma (Option B),
  • Diabetes
  • Hyperlipidemia.

Additional Risk Factors

Smoking, optic disc edema, oral contraceptives, hypercoagulable states (e.g., polycythemia, multiple myeloma, antiphospholipid syndrome, hyperhomocysteinemia, etc.), syphilis, HIV, sickle cell disease.

Pathophysiology

The exact etiology is unknown, but the occlusion of the Central retinal vein posterior to the lamina cribrosa of the optic nerve typically by thrombosis, is a key mechanism. This is contributed by venous stasis and hypercoagulability. Atherosclerosis in the artery can lead to compression of the adjacent vein.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male presents with sudden, severe vision loss in his left eye. On examination, a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is present. Fundus examination reveals the following changes:



Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
on-ischemic vs Ischemic CRVO

Feature

Non-ischemic CRVO (Venous Stasis Retinopathy)

Ischemic CRVO (Hemorrhagic Retinopathy)

Prevalence

75% of cases

25% of cases

Vision

Mild to moderate blurring

Severe, sudden vision loss

RAPD

Absent or mild

Present

Early Fundus Findings

Mild venous congestion, peripheral flame-shaped hemorrhages, mild/no macular edema

Massive venous engorgement, "splashed-tomato" hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, macular edema

Late Fundus Findings

Vein sheathing, cilioretinal collaterals, absorbed hemorrhages, chronic cystoid edema

Marked vein sheathing, collaterals, neovascularization, chronic cystoid edema

Complications

15-30% convert to ischemic CRVO

Neovascular glaucoma, vitreous hemorrhage, proliferative retinopathy

Image

 

Non-ischemic CRVO (Option A) is more common (75% of cases), but it typically presents with milder symptoms, including gradual vision blurring and the absence or mild presence of RAPD. Fundus findings are less severe, with mild venous congestion and flame-shaped hemorrhages in the periphery.

 

Branch Retinal Vein Occlusion (BRVO) (Option C) typically affects a portion of the retina rather than the entire retina, and the hemorrhages are more localized to the area of the occluded vein. Vision loss is generally less severe compared to ischemic CRVO.

 

Diabetic Retinopathy (Option D) can present with retinal hemorrhages and macular edema, but it is not associated with sudden, severe vision loss and RAPD as in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is most useful in distinguishing ischemic CRVO from non-ischemic CRVO?
questions.solution:
Goldmann Perimetry and ERG are crucial for differentiating between ischemic and non-ischemic CRVO. In ischemic CRVO, there is significant retinal ischemia leading to visual field defects and a reduction in the amplitude of the b-wave on ERG. These findings help to confirm the diagnosis of ischemic CRVO.

 

Investigations of CRVO:

 

Investigations

Details

Ocular Examination
  • Visual acuity monitoring
  • IOP measurement
  • Slit-lamp examination for neovascularization of the iris (NVI)
  • Gonioscopy to exclude neovascularization of the angle (NVA)
  • Fundus examination (direct and indirect)

Ocular Investigations
  • Goldmann perimetry: Important for differentiating visual field defects in ischemic from non-ischemic CRVO.
  • ERG: Reduced b-wave amplitude in ischemic CRVO.
  • Fundus autofluorescence (FAF): Demonstrates fern-like perivenular hypo autofluorescence due to retinal edema.
  • FFA: Assess retinal perfusion (Ischemic CRVO shows >10 disc areas of capillary non-perfusion).
  • OCT: To evaluate macular edema, sub-retinal fluid, and epiretinal membrane (ERM) formation.

Systemic Investigations

Check for hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemia, hypercoagulable states, homocysteinemia.

 

Management of CRVO

 

Medical Treatment
  • Intravitreal steroids (triamcinolone, dexamethasone)
  • Intravitreal anti-VEGF (Bevacizumab, Ranibizumab)

Laser Treatment
  • Panretinal Photocoagulation (PRP): Indicated when neovascularization occurs (NVI, NVA, NVE, or NVD).
  • Grid Laser: Not recommended for macular edema in CRVO.

Surgical Treatment

Pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) for complications (vitreous hemorrhage, retinal detachment, ERM)

Glaucoma drainage devices for neovascular glaucoma.

 

Fundus Autofluorescence (FAF) (Option A) demonstrates fern-like perivenular hypoautofluorescence due to retinal edema in both non-ischemic and ischemic CRVO.

 

Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) (Option B) is valuable in evaluating macular edema, which may be present in both non-ischemic and ischemic CRVO. Goldmann perimetry and ERG are most useful in differentiating ischemic from non-ischemic CRVO.

 

Slit-lamp examination (Option D) is essential for detecting anterior segment changes such as neovascularization of the iris (NVI). It is mainly used to monitor for complications like neovascular glaucoma.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with sudden, painless vision loss in his right eye. Which of the following findings is most consistent with the diagnosis of central retinal artery occlusion?

choices.text: Retinal hemorrhages and cotton wool spots
Optic disc edema and retinal hemorrhages
Pale retina with a cherry-red spot at the macula

questions.solution:
In central retinal artery occlusion, the cherry-red spot is seen at the center of the macula due to the vascular choroid shining through the thin foveal retina, contrasting with the surrounding pale retina caused by ischemia.

 

Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO)

 

Risk factors:

  • Atherosclerosis
  • Age
  • Hypertension
  • Cardiac Diseases
    • Atrial fibrillation: promotes blood clot formation, increasing CRAO risk
    • Mitral valve prolapse: this can lead to blood flow abnormalities and clot formation
    • Bacterial endocarditis: causes vegetation that can travel and occlude the retinal artery
  • Thrombophilic disorders
    • Hyperhomocysteinemia: elevated homocysteine levels increase clot formation risk
    • Antiphospholipid syndrome: an autoimmune disorder causing increased clot formation risk
    • Inherited anticoagulant defects: genetic conditions disrupting natural blood clotting regulation
  • Giant cell arteritis (GCA)
    • Inflammatory condition affecting blood vessels, often with severe visual loss
  • Other factors
    • Smoking
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Oral contraceptive pills


 

Clinical features:

 

Symptoms:

  • Sudden, painless, profound vision loss
  • Painless, except in GCA: GCA-associated CRAO may present with headache, jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, and/or pain around the temple

 

Clinical Signs:

  • Visual Acuity (VA): severely reduced, often to counting fingers or worse
  • Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD): Profound and sometimes total (amaurotic pupil)

 

Fundus Examination:

  • Retinal Whitening: Pale and opaque retina, particularly in the posterior pole
  • Cherry-Red Spot: Bright red area at the fovea due to the contrast between pale retina and underlying choroidal circulation
  • Cattle truck appearance: Due to segmentation of blood column in retinal veins
  • Attenuated Arteries: Narrowed and segmented retinal arterioles
  • Optic Disc Changes: Pale optic disc over time due to optic atrophy from prolonged ischemia is seen in chronic cases.
  •  

    Fluorescein Angiography (FA)

  • Arterial Filling: Delayed
  • Masking of Background Fluorescence: Edematous retina blocks normal fluorescence from the choroid
  • Patent Cilioretinal Artery: Area of normal perfusion if a cilioretinal artery supplies the fovea, potentially preserving central vision

  • Other Diagnostic Tests

    Reveals retinal edema, structural changes, and possibly an embolic plaque within the retinal artery and other systemic causes.

  • Cranial MRI or CT
  • Carotid duplex scanning
  • Echocardiography
  • Thrombophilia screening

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with Type 2 diabetes undergoes a fundus examination, revealing extensive retinal hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, venous beading, and moderate intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in one quadrant. What is the most appropriate follow-up interval for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 4 months

Explanation:

The presence of extensive retinal hemorrhages, venous beading, and moderate IRMA in one quadrant indicates severe non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR). For severe NPDR, the follow-up interval is every 4 months.

 

Abbreviated Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) classification of diabetic retinopathy

Category

Management

Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR)

No Diabetic Retinopathy

Review in 12 months

Very Mild NPDR

Microaneurysms only

Review most patients in 12 months

(Option D)

Mild NPDR

Any or all of the: microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and cotton-wool spots, up to the level of moderate NPDR. No intraretinal microvascular anomalies (IRMA) or significant beading.

Review range 6-12 months, depending on the severity of signs, stability, systemic factors, and patient's circumstances

Moderate NPDR

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA
  • Significant venous beading can be present in no more than 1 quadrant
  • Cotton wool spots commonly present

Review in approximately 6 months

(Option C)

Severe NPDR

The 4-2-1 rule; is one or more of the:

  • Severe hemorrhages in all 4 quadrants
  • Significant venous beading in 2 or more quadrants
  • Moderate IRMA in 1 or more quadrants

Review in 4 months (Option B)

Very severe NPDR

Two or more of the criteria for severe NPDR

Review in 2-3 months (Option A)

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR)

Mild-moderate PDR

New vessels on the disc (NVD) or new vessels elsewhere (NVE), but extent insufficient to meet the high-risk criteria

Treatment is considered according to the severity of signs, stability, systemic factors, and the patient's circumstances such as reliability of attendance for review. If not treated, review in up to 2 months

High-risk PDR

  • NVD greater than ⅓ disc area
  • Any NVD with vitreous hemorrhage
  • NVE greater than ½ disc area with vitreous hemorrhage

Treatment should be performed immediately when possible and certainly on the same day if symptomatic presentation with a good retinal view

Advanced diabetic eye disease

Is characterized by tractional retinal detachment. Significant persistent vitreous hemorrhage and neovascular glaucoma.

Vitreoretinal surgery with photocoagulation
  • PRP of ischemic area reduces metabolic demand and prevents the release of vasoproliferative factors by conversion of hypoxic areas into anoxic areas and creates inert scars from leaking vascular anomalies.
  • Laser used: Argon, frequency-doubled YAG or diode laser
  • In PRP, the inferior quadrant of the retina is first coagulated.
  • Untreated Areas: A circular area with a radius of 2.5 DD around the fovea is left untouched during treatment.
  • Each treatment requires 2000-3000 burns, administered over two to four sessions.
  • Anti-VEGF Therapy:
    • Bevacizumab, ranibizumab or aflibercept are used to control neovascularization.
  • Vitreoretinal Surgery: Advanced cases with tractional retinal detachment or unresolved vitreous hemorrhage require vitrectomy.

questions.text: A cherry-red spot is seen on the retina due to thickening and loss of transparency of the retina at the posterior pole. Which of the following diseases are least associated with this finding on fundoscopy?
questions.solution:
Central retinal vein occlusion causes mild blurring of vision and, on fundoscopy, shows superficial flame-shaped hemorrhages, papilloedema, mild or no macular edema in acute cases and sheathing of main veins, chronic cystoid edema in chronic cases. A cherry-red spot is not seen in central retinal vein occlusion.

Conditions with Cherry-red spot:

A) Metabolic storage diseases:

Causes pathological accumulation of lipid-based material in various tissues.

The spot becomes less evident with time and there is optic atrophy.


They are:

  • GM1 gangliosidosis
  • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
  • GM2 gangliosidosis: Tay-Sachs disease (Option A) and Sandhoff disease
  • Niemann-Pick disease: three types A-C
  • Type A and B present with a cherry-red spot
  • Type C presents with ocular motility issues
  • Farber disease (Option B)

 

B) Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion (Option C)

  • Retinal clouding from edema
  • Acute sign

 

C) Retinotoxicity

  • Quinine
  • Dapsone
  • Gentamicin
  • Carbon monoxide
  • Methanol

 

D) Commotio retinae

Edema due to blunt trauma

 

E) Miscellaneous

  • Conditions giving a dark or reddish central macular appearance
  • Ex: Macular hole

questions.text: A patient is being examined for loss of vision in the ophthalmology clinic. His peripheral visual field is lost, and only his central vision remains. Which of the following would not present with central (tunnel) vision?
questions.solution:
Tobacco amblyopia presents with loss of central vision and not with its preservation.

  • It is caused by excessive use of tobacco, and the toxic agent is cyanide in tobacco which leads to degeneration of ganglion cells, especially in the macula.
  • It characteristically presents with impairment of central vision, which is bilateral and progressive, with patients complaining of difficulty in doing near work and fogginess.

 

Central vision, tubular vision, or tunnel vision refers to the loss of peripheral vision while preserving central vision.

Causes of tubular vision:

  • Terminal stage of advanced glaucomatous field defect (Option A):
    • The visual field loss is gradual, both centrally and peripherally.
    • Only a small island of central and temporal vision is left.
    • Prolonged damage leads to loss of central vision as well.
    • The temporal island is more resistant and hence is lost only in the end, leading to loss of even light perception.
  • Advanced stage of retinitis pigmentosa (Option B):
    • It is a disorder that, if sporadic, has a more favorable diagnosis with a retained central vision till the 6th decade of life.
    • Central vision occurs in advanced cases and is lost ultimately after a prolonged duration.
  • Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) with cilioretinal artery (Option C):
    • The cilioretinal artery is found in one-third of the eyes.
    • It provides a second arterial supply to the fovea and hence in the case of CRAO, the central vision is maintained whereas the peripheral is lost.
  • Vigabatrin:
    • It is a drug used in the treatment of epilepsy
    • It can cause vision loss in 30% of infants and causes bilateral tunnel vision in adults
    • Vigabatrin causes damage to the central retina and leads to visual acuity

questions.text: A premature infant, born at 26 weeks of gestation, is receiving oxygen therapy in the neonatal intensive care unit. Retinal examination at 4 weeks post-birth reveals signs of retinal vascular abnormalities. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for the pathogenesis of retinopathy of prematurity in this patient?

choices.text: Increased oxygen supply leading to retinal vasodilation
Retinal hypoxia leading to abnormal collagen formation

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Disruption of VEGF production

Explanation:

In retinopathy of prematurity, the premature infant's retina is vulnerable to abnormal vascular growth. The disruption of VEGF production, often due to fluctuations in oxygen levels (e.g., excess oxygen therapy), impairs the normal retinal vascular development. This can lead to abnormal blood vessel formation and progression of ROP.

 

Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) is a bilateral proliferative retinopathy in premature infants with low birth weight, commonly due to high oxygen exposure.

 

Risk Factors:

  • Birth weight of <1.5 kg

  • Gestational age <32 weeks

  • Supplemental oxygen therapy

 

Pathogenesis:

  • Retinal vessels extend to the nasal edge by the eighth month of gestation but the temporal periphery vascularizes about a month after birth, by the effect of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF).

  • Premature birth downregulates VEGF, halting vessel migration.

  • Immature vessels are damaged by oxygen exposure, causing vasoconstriction and eventually obliteration of retinal arteries and veins.

  • As the infant grows, metabolic demands increase leading to excess production of oxygen-regulated VEGF and non-oxygen-regulated insulin-like growth factor (IGF).

  • This leads to neovascularization and fibrous proliferation.

  • These changes cause progressive stages of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP).

  • Retinal Changes:

    • Early signs: Dilatation of retinal veins, hazy white patches in the peripheral retina.

    • Proliferation of new vessels into the vitreous from the retina, forming fibrous tissue.

    • Progression: Retinal detachment, microphthalmia, and varying degrees of vision loss.

 

Increased oxygen supply leading to retinal vasodilation (Option A): Excessive oxygen therapy causes retinal vessel suppression, not vasodilation.

Excessive blood glucose levels (Option C): ROP is not directly caused by blood glucose levels, but by oxygen fluctuations.

Retinal hypoxia leading to abnormal collagen formation (Option D): Hypoxia triggers VEGF production, causing abnormal vessel growth, not collagen deposition.

questions.text: A 32-week premature infant presents with dilated and tortuous retinal vessels in the posterior pole, poor pupil dilation, and vitreous haze, indicating a progression of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Plus disease is indicated by severe retinal vessel changes, including dilatation and tortuosity and a progression of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). It is often associated with poor pupillary dilation and vitreous haze.

 

Classification of ROP:

  1. Active disease: Neovascularization, and visual disturbances, may resolve on its own.
  2. Cicatricial disease: (Option C)
    • About 20% of infants with active ROP develop cicatricial (scar tissue) complications.
    • Findings include temporal vitreoretinal fibrosis and vascular arcade straightening with macula and disc dragging.
    • Severe cases may show retrolental fibrovascular tissue, leading to retinal folds and retinal detachment (retrolental fibroplasia).

      Plus Disease

      (Option B)

      Rush Disease/ Aggressive Posterior ROP

      (Option A)

      • Defined by dilatation and tortuosity of posterior pole vessels in at least two quadrants with any stage of ROP.

      • Associated with engorgement and dilatation of the iris vessel, poor pupil dilation and vitreous haze.

      • Indicates a tendency for disease progression.
      • Located in zone I or posterior zone II with severe plus disease.
      • Characterized by flat proliferation with vascular loops, hemorrhages and absence of any stage.
      • Requires immediate treatment due to rapid progression.
      • Can progress directly to stage 5 ROP without passing through earlier stages.

    • Stage 4 ROP (Option A) involves tractional retinal detachment that extends from the periphery to the posterior pole, not characterized by vessel changes typical of plus disease.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents with sudden, painless vision loss in his left eye. Fundus examination reveals peripheral retinal vasculitis, vessel sheathing and recurrent vitreous hemorrhages. Fluorescein angiography reveals vessel leakage. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Eales disease is an idiopathic peripheral retinal vasculopathy that presents with recurrent vitreous hemorrhages. In the early stage of the disease, characterized by active retinal vasculitis, systemic corticosteroids are the treatment of choice. They reduce inflammation and help prevent further vascular damage and hemorrhage.

Venous congestion, perivascular exudates and sheets of hemorrhages present near the affected veins in Eales disease


 

Feature

Description

Population Affected

Young males

Etiology

Hypersensitivity reaction (Type IV or III) to tuberculoproteins, causing retinal vasculitis, resulting in retinal hypoxia and vasoproliferation

Vasculitis Manifestation

Vessel sheathing, extensive leakage on fluorescein angiography

Retinal Changes

Hemorrhages, soft exudates, retinal edema, neovascularization, and arteriovenous shunt vessels

Complications

Recurrent vitreous hemorrhage, tractional retinal detachment, secondary glaucoma

Initial Treatment

Systemic steroids for early vasculitis

Further Management

Photocoagulation for vessels under traction, vitreoretinal surgery for severe cases

 

Intravitreal anti-VEGF therapy (Option A) is used in conditions involving neovascularization, such as diabetic retinopathy, they are not the primary treatment for Eales disease, which is mainly driven by inflammation rather than VEGF-mediated neovascularization.

Laser photocoagulation (Option C) is indicated for treating areas of retinal ischemia and neovascularization in the later stages of the disease, not in the early stages.

Vitrectomy (Option D) is usually done for cases where there is persistent vitreous hemorrhage that does not resolve on its own, or if there is tractional retinal detachment.

questions.text: What is the approximate distance of the fovea from the optic disc in a normal eye?

choices.text: 1 disc diameter temporal to the optic disc
2 disc diameters nasal to the optic disc
2 disc diameters temporal to the optic disc
1 disc diameter nasal to the optic disc

questions.solution:
The fovea is situated approximately 2 disc diameters (DD) away from the optic disc on the temporal side. 1 disc diameter is equal to about 1.5 mm, so the fovea is located approximately 3 mm from the optic disc. (Options A, B, and C)

 

The Macula

Structure

Description

Function

Macula lutea (clinical posterior pole)

A 5.5 mm diameter cone-rich region in the retina.

Responsible for central vision and color vision.

Fovea

A 1.5 mm diameter area at the center of the macula, 2 disc diameters temporal to the optic disc.

Provides sharp, detailed vision.

Foveola

A 0.35 mm diameter central depression within the fovea, often shows a bright foveal reflex.

Contains only cones, facilitating the highest visual acuity.

Foveal avascular zone

A 0.4–0.6 mm diameter zone surrounds the foveola, devoid of retinal blood vessels.

Enhances visual clarity by reducing interference from blood vessels.

questions.text: In which layer of the retina, as labeled in the histology image, are the cell bodies of bipolar cells located?
questions.solution:
The Inner Nuclear Layer is made up of the cell bodies of bipolar cells, horizontal cells, and amacrine cells. It is labeled as B in the Histology image given.

Layer

Description

1. Pigment Epithelium

Outermost layer with a single pigmented cell layer; adheres to Bruch's membrane; supports neurosensory retina, and reduces reflection.

Subretinal Space: This is the layer between the Pigment epithelium and the layer of Photoreceptors.

2. Rods and Cones Layer

Contains the outer segments of photoreceptors (rods and cones, which are the first-order neurons); rods detect low-light vision, cones manage color and detailed vision.

3. External Limiting Membrane

A porous membrane allows processes from rods and cones to pass through.

4. Outer Nuclear Layer
(Henle’s layer) (Option D)

Contains the nuclei of the photoreceptor cells (rods and cones).

5. Outer Plexiform Layer (Option C)

Includes connections between rods, cones, bipolar cell dendrites, and horizontal cells.

6. Inner Nuclear Layer (Option B)

Made up of the cell bodies of bipolar cells (which are the second-order neurons), horizontal cells, amacrine cells, and Müller cells; and also contains retinal capillaries.

7. Inner Plexiform Layer (Option A)

Houses synaptic connections between bipolar cell axons, ganglion cell dendrites, and amacrine cell processes.

8. Ganglion Cell Layer

Contains ganglion cell bodies, which serve as third-order neurons; midget cells synapse with a single bipolar cell, and polysynaptic cells synapse with multiple.

9. Nerve Fiber Layer

Composed of ganglion cell axons that form the optic nerve after passing through the lamina cribrosa.

10. Internal Limiting Membrane

The innermost layer separating the retina from the vitreous; is formed by the terminal expansions of Müller cells, serving as a basement membrane.


 

The Neuroglial cells, particularly the vertical Müller cells, bind the retina's neural elements. These cells provide structural support and nourish the retinal tissue.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and atherosclerosis presents with sudden, painless loss of vision in his left eye. On fundoscopy, you note a pale retina with a cherry-red spot at the macula. What is the most likely underlying cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
• The presentation of sudden, painless vision loss with a cherry-red spot at the macula is highly suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).

  • In cases of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO), the central retinal artery is blocked, causing widespread retinal ischemia.

 

Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO)

Etiology:

  • Obstruction at the level of the lamina cribrosa.

Symptoms:

  • Sudden, painless vision loss (occurs within seconds).
  • History of transient visual loss (amaurosis fugax) in some patients.

Signs:

  1. Visual acuity: Markedly reduced (<3/60 in 90% of cases).
  2. Pupillary reflex: Direct reflex absent, relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) positive.
  3. Fundus Examination:
    • Marked narrowing of retinal arteries, mild narrowing of veins.
    • Milky white retina due to ischemic edema.
    • Cilioretinal artery may preserve part of the macula's normal color.
    • Cherry-red spot at the center of the macula due to the vascular choroid shining through the thin retina.
    • Cattle trucking: Segmentation of blood column in retinal veins.
    • Atrophic changes: Grossly attenuated arteries and optic atrophy in long-standing cases.

Imaging Studies:

  1. OCT: Hyperreflectivity with thickening of inferior retina.
  2. Autofluorescence Imaging: Reduced autofluorescence.
  3. Fundus Fluorescein Angiography (FFA):
    • Delayed arterial filling.
    • Masking of choroidal vasculature due to retinal edema.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries is primarily responsible for supplying the inner layers of the retina?
questions.solution:
The central retinal artery is the main vessel responsible for supplying the inner layers of the retina, including the nerve fiber layer, ganglion cells, and inner retinal layers. The short posterior ciliary arteries primarily supply the choroid and the outer retinal layers.

 

Blood Supply of Retina:

The retina is supplied mainly by the central retinal artery, which enters the optic nerve on its lower surface. It emerges from the optic disc and divides into two branches to form a superior and an inferior trunk, and each trunk divides into two branches: Nasal and temporal.

 

Venous drainage of the optic disc is mainly carried out by the central retinal vein. Retinal veins follow the arteries and drain into the cavernous sinus or superior ophthalmic vein. Retinal venous occlusion can cause hemorrhages - Splash tomato appearance.

 

Layer/Region

Blood Supply

Clinical Relevance

Outer four layers

Supplied by the choroidal vascular system (short and long posterior ciliary arteries).

Avascular layers; rely on choroidal vessels for nutrition

Inner six layers

Supplied by the central retinal artery (branch of ophthalmic artery).

Occlusion causes retinal ischemia.

Macula (in some individuals)

Supplied by the cilioretinal artery (from posterior ciliary arteries).

Preserves central vision during CRAO.

questions.text: The blood-retinal barrier separates the blood from the ocular cavity. Which of the following does not constitute the outer blood-retinal barrier?
questions.solution:
The blood-retinal barrier (BRB) consists of an inner and outer barrier that separates the blood from the ocular cavity, where the retinal vascular endothelial cells form the inner blood-retinal barrier.

 

Features

Outer blood-retinal barrier

Inner blood-retinal barrier

Components

  • Formed by the adjacent cells of the retinal pigment epithelium(RPE) (Option B).
  • Maintained by tight junctions named “zonula occludens” (Option C).
  • RPE rests on the Bruch’s membrane (Option A), which separates the neural retina from the choroid capillaries.
  • Formed by the tight junctions between the endothelial cells of the retinal blood vessels.
  • Depends on capillary integrity.

Function

It prevents the leakage of extracellular fluid and nutrients from the choroid to the outer retina.

Controls permeability of the retinal blood vessels.

Factors affecting the BRB
  • Prostaglandins
  • Leukotrienes
  • Protein kinase C
  • Nitric oxide
  • VEGF
  • Other cytokines

Associated pathology
  • Outer BRB damage is seen in conditions like:
    • Age-related macular degeneration
    • Central serous chorioretinopathy
    • Accelerated hypertension
    • Toxemia of pregnancy
  • Breakdown of outer BRB leads to:
    • Retinal detachment or
    • RPE detachment
  • Retinal macroaneurysms cause a breakage in the inner blood-retinal barrier and accumulation of fluid within the outer neurosensory retina.
  • Involved in conditions like:
    • Cystoid macular edema.
    • Diabetic retinopathy
    • Retinal vein occlusion

Hypofluorescence due to blockage of background fluorescence by retinal hemorrhage
Hypofluorescence due to occlusion of retinal vasculature

  • Fundus Disorders: Identifies depth of pathological involvement.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with difficulty in vision, especially at night, and he reports bumping into objects frequently. Upon examination, he is found to have tunnel vision, and the fundus reveals no abnormalities in the posterior pole. Which region of the retina is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The presentation of diminished night vision and loss of peripheral vision is suggestive of a defect in the peripheral retina, which is crucial for peripheral and night vision. Additionally, no abnormality was found in the posterior pole, which includes the macula, fovea, and optic disc.

Part

Description

Posterior Pole

The region behind the retinal equator includes the optic disc and macula lutea; best examined using slit-lamp biomicroscopy or by direct ophthalmoscopy.

Optic Disc (Option C)

Known as the optic nerve head, it is a pink, vertically oval structure, marking the start of the optic nerve.

The physiological Cup is a depression in the optic disc through which the central retinal artery and vein pass; the absence of photoreceptors results in the physiological blind spot.

Macula Lutea (Option A)

A dark, yellow spot at the posterior pole, measuring 5.5 mm in diameter; is responsible for central, high-acuity vision and color detection.

Fovea Centralis (Option B)

Central area of the macula (1.5 mm in diameter); contains only cones and is the most sensitive part of the retina for visual acuity.

Foveola

A 0.35 mm diameter shining pit within the fovea, represents the area of highest visual acuity, with the foveal avascular zone (FAZ) surrounding it.

Peripheral Retina (Option D)

Extends from the retinal equator to the ora serrata, examined via indirect ophthalmoscopy or Goldmann three-mirror lens. It contains rods, hence responsible for night vision.

Ora Serrata

The serrated peripheral margin is where the retina ends. Here the retina is firmly attached to both the vitreous and choroid. Pars plana extends anteriorly from ora serrata.

choices.text:
Extinguished ERG response
B) Subnormal ERG with a reduced b-wave
C) Negative ERG response
D) Normal ERG with a diminished c-wave
Subnormal ERG with a reduced b-wave
Normal ERG with a diminished c-wave

questions.solution:
Electroretinogram (ERG)

 

Definition

Electroretinography (ERG) records changes in the eye's resting potential. It is induced by a flash of light.

Parts of ERG
  • A-wave: Negative wave, likely from rods and cones (photoreceptors).
  • B-wave: Large positive wave, generated by Müller cells (inner retinal layers) but reflects bipolar cell activity.
  • C-wave: Positive wave, related to the metabolic activity of the pigment epithelium (RPE), observed in dark-adapted eyes.
  • Foveal ERG provides information about the macula used in diagnosing cataracts.

Interpretation

Response

Inference

Extinguished

Complete failure in rod and cone function (e.g., pigmentary retinal dystrophy, complete retinal artery occlusion, old retinal detachment, advanced siderosis).

Subnormal

Large areas of the retina not functioning (e.g., early retinitis pigmentosa, before ophthalmoscopic signs).

Negative

Gross disturbances in the retinal circulation.

Clinical uses
  • Used in diagnosis and prognosis for retinal disorders like retinitis pigmentosa, Leber's congenital amaurosis, retinal ischemia, and chorioretinal degenerations.
  • Assessment in Unclear Conditions: Evaluates retinal junction when fundus examination is not possible (e.g., dense cataract, corneal opacity).
  • Infant Vision Assessment: Assesses retinal junction in infants with suspected impaired vision.

Patterns in ERG

Pattern ERG

Changes in PERG responses can occur in the early stages of glaucoma by measuring the activity of retinal ganglion cells (RGCs), often correlating with elevated intraocular pressure (IOP).

Multifocal ERG
  • mfERG aids in diagnosing macular diseases like Stargardt dystrophy, cone dystrophy, and occult macular dystrophy.
  • mfERG or similar objective tests can be used to screen chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine toxicity.

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presents with progressive visual impairment. Upon examination, there is evidence of vitelliform lesions in the macula. Electro-oculography (EOG) is performed to assess retinal function. What Arden ratio would be expected in a patient with Best disease on electro-oculography (EOG)?

In Best disease, the Arden ratio on EOG is typically less than 1.5, indicating abnormal retinal pigment epithelium function, which is characteristic of this condition.

 

Electro-oculography (EOG):

  • Measures changes in resting ocular potential via electrodes placed at inner and outer canthi when eyes move side to side.
  • Changes in potential reflect the activity of retinal pigment epithelium (regulated by the bestrophin gene) and outer segments of visual receptors.

 

Clinical Use:

  • Useful in detecting retinal pigment epithelium dystrophies and degenerations before visual symptoms manifest.
  • Helpful in diagnosing Best disease (Arden index <1.5) and differentiating it from adult-onset vitelliform macular dystrophy and pattern dystrophy. (Option B)
  • EOG apparatus can also be used to record eye movements in nystagmus (electronystagmography (ENG)).

 

Arden Index: The result is calculated by dividing the light peak (maximal potential in light) by the dark trough (minimal potential in dark).

Interpretation

Normal

1.85-1.5

  • Retinopathy of prematurity
  • Sickle cell retinopathy
  • Retinal artery occlusive disease, etc.











 

General pathogenesis

 
  • Diabetic retinopathy (DR):
  • Capillary basement membrane thickening, endothelial cell damage, RBCs deformation, and rouleaux formation, increased stickiness of platelets, increased plasma viscosity, loss of capillary pericytes → microvascular occlusion (cotton wool spots), retinal ischemia → leads to the clinical appearances of DR.
  • Progress of retinal changes in diabetic retinopathy:
    • Diabetic macular edema → Macular ischemia (Option A) → Retinal new vessels (Option B) → Vitreous hemorrhage (Option C) → Tractional retinal detachment.

Hypertensive retinopathy:

  • Systemic hypertension causes vasoconstriction of retinal arterioles (Option D)
  • Arteriosclerosis, increased vascular permeability, and retinal hemorrhages lead to retinopathy.

Retinopathy of prematurity:

  • In premature infants
  • Linked to high-oxygen exposure
  • Leads to abnormal neovascularization and retinal hypoxia

Sickle cell retinopathy:

  • Due to abnormal RBCs
  • Vascular occlusion and retinal damage lead to retinopathy.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with worsening vision. Fundoscopy reveals retinal edema, microaneurysms, and hard exudates. Which of the following mechanisms is not responsible for the development of diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
Reduced blood viscosity is not a contributing factor to diabetic retinopathy; instead, increased blood viscosity is observed.

 

Risk Factors of Diabetic Retinopathy:

  1. Duration of Diabetes: Increases the risk regardless of disease severity or control. Develops after 10 years of diabetes and affects the majority of patients after 20 years.
  2. Poor Diabetic Control accelerates the onset and progression of diabetic retinopathy.
  3. Systemic Hypertension
  4. Poor Renal Status
  5. Pregnancy
  6. Other risk factors: Smoking, obesity, anemia, and hyperlipidemia

 

Pathogenesis of Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • Cellular Damage: Produces damage to the cells of the retina, endothelial cells, loss of pericytes, and thickening of basement membrane by:
    • Increased sorbitol accumulation
    • Accumulation of advanced glycation end products (AGEs)
    • Protein kinase C activation (Option A)
    • Activation of eicosanoids, nitric oxides and intracellular adhesion molecules
    • Excessive oxidative stress
  • Hematological and Biochemical Changes:
    • Increased platelet adhesiveness
    • Increased blood viscosity (Option B)
    • Red blood cell deformation and rouleaux formation
    • Altered serum lipids
    • Increased leukostasis
    • Increased fibrinolysis
  • Effects of Microangiopathy:
    • Breakdown of the blood-retinal barrier (Option D)
    • Weakened capillary walls
    • Microvascular occlusion
    • Neovascularization induced by:
      • Proangiogenic factors: Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) (Option C)
  • Reduced anti-angiogenic factors: Decreased levels of endostatin, angiostatin, pigment-derived growth factor (PEDF), thrombospondin-1, and platelet factor 4

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a long history of diabetes mellitus presents for a routine eye examination. The ophthalmologist noted several findings in the retinal examination. Which of the following features is least likely to be observed in early nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)?
questions.solution:
Venous beading is typically associated with severe non-progressive diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) or preproliferative diabetic retinopathy, and indicates sluggish retinal circulation.

 

Classification of Non-Progressive Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR)

Severity

Definition

Very mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms only

Mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms plus hard exudates, cotton-wool spots, and/or mild retinal hemorrhages

Moderate nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms plus mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities or moderate retinal hemorrhages

Severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Any one of the following (4-2-1 Rule)

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in four quadrants
  • Venous beading in at least two
  • Moderately severe intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in at least one quadrant

Very severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Any two of the following (4-2-1 Rule)

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in four quadrants
  • Venous beading in at least two
  • Moderately severe intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in at least one quadrant

 

Clinical Features:

 

Early NPDR or Background Diabetic Retinopathy

Severe NPDR or Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy
  • Affects small retinal vessels.
  • Earliest sign: Microaneurysm (Option A)
    • Fluorescein angiography (FA): Tiny hyperfluorescent dots.
  • Retinal hemorrhages: Both deep, i.e., in the inner nuclear or outer plexiform layer (dot and blot hemorrhage) and superficial, i.e., in nerve fiber layer (splinter or flame-shaped) hemorrhages (Option B)
  • Hard exudates:
    • White or yellow waxy patches with well-defined margins, often at the posterior pole, in the outer plexiform layer. (Option C)
    • FA: Hypofluorescence with dense exudates.
  • Edema is not marked.
  • Increased inner retinal hypoxia: Leads to multiple retinal hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, venous beading, vascular loops, intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMAs), and large areas of capillary nonperfusion.
  • Cotton-Wool Spots:
    • Also called soft exudates or nerve fiber infarcts.
    • Result from ischemia, not exudation.
    • Caused by obstruction of axoplasmic flow, leading to swelling and a white, fluffy appearance.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence due to local ischemia.
  • Venous Beading:
    • Indicates sluggish retinal circulation.
    • Typically adjacent to large areas of capillary nonperfusion. (Option D)
  • Intraretinal Microvascular Abnormalities (IRMA):
    • Dilated capillaries act as collateral channels.
    • Bypass capillary bed and is often seen adjacent to capillary nonperfusion.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with chronic diabetes is diagnosed with diabetic retinopathy. What is the most specific finding for confirming proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) in this patient?
questions.solution:
Neovascularization of the Disc (NVD) is the most specific finding for confirming proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR).

 

Clinical Features of Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR):

  • Includes all features of preproliferative diabetic retinopathy or severe NPDR: Multiple retinal hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, venous beading, vascular loops, intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMAs), and large areas of capillary nonperfusion along with neovascularization. (Options A, B, D)
  •  
  • Neovascularization (2 types):
    • Neovascularization of the Disc (NVD): Arises within 1 disc diameter of the optic nerve from the optic nerve head. (Option C)
    • Neovascularization Elsewhere (NVE): Arises more than 1 disc diameter from the optic nerve, along the large vessels.
    • Appears adjacent to areas of capillary closure and the accompanying fibrous tissue varies in extent.
    • Fluorescein angiography (FA): Irregular expanding hyperfluorescence.
  • Severe Vision Loss: Result in vision as poor as hand movements or worse due to severe vitreous hemorrhage or retinal detachment.
  • Fibrovascular Tissue Formation:
    • Formed due to condensation of connective tissue around the new vessels.
    • Lie flat on the retina or attach to the posterior vitreous face.
    • Can lead to vitreous traction, retinal separation, and blood vessel tearing.
    • The most common cause of vitreous hemorrhage in adults.
  • Rubeosis Iridis: Neovascularization of iris.
  • Neovascular glaucoma: Occurs due neovascularization of anterior segment angle.
